Noughts &amp; Crosses Review, York Theatre Royal

12/10/2022

Alanah Hammond reviews the thought-provoking adaptation of Malorie Blackmanâ€™s critically acclaimed novel

Image by Robert Day

By Alanah Hammond

Malorie Blackmanâ€™s critically acclaimed novel Noughts & Crosses was first adapted for the stage in 2019. Now, three years on, the show is back, offering the audience at York Theatre Royal a stimulating spectacle.

The novel and play are set in a racially segregated society, but contrary to our own world history, it is now black people (Crosses) who are the ruling elite. In this society, recognisable but different, white people (Noughts) are subjected to racial discrimination and inferiority.

We see this milieu unfold through the perspective of teenagers Sephy, played by Effie Ansah, and Callum, played by James Arden, who both deliver impressive first lead-role debuts.

They convincingly portray a forbidden and dangerous love, much like that of Shakespeareâ€™s classic play Romeo and Juliet. This is because Sephyâ€™s father, played by Chris Jack, is one of the leading figures of Cross authority whereas Callumâ€™s family is at the extreme opposite, involved in the â€œLiberation Militiaâ€ which is a white freedom party.

The play itself, adapted by Sabrina Mahfouz, has careful parallels throughout. For example, Sephy and Callumâ€™s parallels are their intertwined key moments: the first is how for â€œthree yearsâ€ Sephyâ€™s mum has been an alcoholic, whereas Callumâ€™s sister, for â€œthree yearsâ€, hasnâ€™t been seen or heard and stays in her room.

A second parallel in the play is the death of Sephyâ€™s mum from an overdose and the tragic death of Callumâ€™s sister in a road â€œaccidentâ€. In this latter scene, where we learn of Callumâ€™s sisterâ€™s death, we are told that she committed suicide because she could no longer bear to be a Nought. We later find out that this is because she was racially attacked by Noughts for loving a Cross, which again highlights the theme of forbidden love.

The last similarity is shown in the second act, after a very long first half. We learn that for â€œthree yearsâ€ Sephy has been at boarding school, whereas Callum is now serving in the Liberation Militia as Sergeant McGregor.

After his fatherâ€™s death for being a rebel, Callum sees violence as the only option. Unfortunately, through this decision, Callum reaches the same fate as his father: the towering stairs, leading towards a noose, dominate the stage, and Callum is killed for the cause of the Liberation Militia.

Despite such morbidity, we do see Sephy and Callumâ€™s love endure through the birth of their child. At the end of the play, we see her give birth which is the biggest parallel of the whole play, as it comes full circle. In the beginning, we saw Sephy on the stage with this same child, and by the end we cyclically return to this exact scene.

Another cyclical motif was demonstrated by the set of the stage, which was flashy and obtrusive. Simon Kenny and Ben Cowens worked on the design and lighting to create a stark red Nought and Cross symbol that recurred throughout the play.

Such big themes, such as racial segregation or forbidden love, are importantly at play within Noughts & Crosses. It gives the audience, which is often made up of a range of age groups, an insight into the not so distant past, as well as the present, in a really engaging way.

For example, at York Theatre Royal, the audience included a class of teenage pupils from the local school, who sat in front of me. During one scene, when Sephy is beaten up in the girls bathroom for being friends with the Noughts, one young student audibly said â€œthatâ€™s disgustingâ€, which was such a pure and real reaction to the performance. They were all certainly horrified but captivated by what they were seeing because we know that such violence did happen, and unfortunately, continues to happen.

This kind of racial violence was highlighted in the programme. In 2022, racist attacks increased in England from previous years, which was described as â€œa grim barometer for the current state of the nationâ€. We were told that a Home Office report attributes this to â€œtrigger eventsâ€ such as the â€œbacklashâ€ by right wing extremists to Black Lives Matter.

With such a turbulent reality, it was so important that Director Esther Richardson was sensitive but also not shy of the truth. We saw this balancing act in a range of scenes, from one Nought putting a black skin tone plaster on their face (they don't make any for white skin) to the mass protests from Crosses when it was announced that Noughts would be going to Cross schools.

These scenes were really thought-provoking, as such historical events were brought to the stage for us to visually see, rather than reading about them in history books. Theatre needs to respond to the present moment and Noughts & Crosses certainly does this, offering all ages a very important insight and reminder of our history, our present and the future we can influence.
